awd_titl_txt: Examining the 'Class Ceiling' in Big Tech
awd_abstract_narration:
The project examines whether and how the class ceiling impacts the STEM workforce by focusing on the application and hiring process of elite internships, a key juncture in the path towards careers in Big Tech.  By simultaneously studying the hiring process at Big Tech firms from the demand side evaluations of job applicants by employers and supply side choices and preparation of job applicants, the research will illuminate the hidden factors that shape who is offered elite internships. It fills a fundamental gap in the knowledge base by investigating the role of class background in hiring for these STEM jobs.  While assumed to be minimal due to the emphasis on ?objective? technical skills, pilot data suggest hiring decisions for these internships are influenced by tacit markers of class background such as organizational fit, individual fit, social networks, and communication style.  Such inductive findings motivate the current project, which will examine the relationship between class background and the attainment of elite internships with a larger sample and more rigorous mixed-methods design.  The research will provide STEM organizations with concrete ways to facilitate equitable and inclusive hiring practices and enable underprivileged applicants to navigate the hiring process by equipping them with knowledge about the expectations of the dominant hiring culture.

The goal of the project is to examine how class figures into the attainment of elite research internships in the top tech companies such as Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Amazon.  Investigators will examine two research questions: (1) How does the role of class background shape internship attainment through gatekeeper evaluations? and (2) How does class background shape internship applicant preparation, interview performance and outcomes. Data will be collected primarily through interviews, observations at Big Tech recruitment events and internship preparation seminars, questionnaires.  The study is the first to study how class background shapes hiring in a technical profession, extends our understanding of how class shapes hiring beyond the influence of childhood participation in organized activities, and investigates how class shapes applicants? preparation, self-presentation, and hiring outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project examines whether and how class and racial ceilings impacts the STEM workforce by focusing on the application and hiring process of elite internships, a key juncture in the path towards careers in Big Tech. The goal of the project was to examine how class and racial background figures into the attainment of elite research internships in the top tech companies such as Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Amazon.

This research provides much needed nuance and insight to our current understanding and knowledge of inequality in hiring in elite occupations. Prior scholarship has shown that class matters for occupational attainment and that race and gender bias hiring decisions. But much less is known about the role of class in the hiring process and how this varies by race.

Through a series of qualitative and experimental studies, our research reveals the nuanced mechanisms underlying how and why hiring decision-makers inadvertently reproduce inequality through organizational practices that reward class and race-privileged applicants. Specifically, we find that organizational decision makers favor applicants with class- and race-privileged interaction styles, hobbies, and network strategies. We also find that applicants from outside the upper middle class spend more time preparing for interviews and find them more emotionally taxing than those who are members of the upper middle class. As a result, elite occupations unconsciously end up reproducing their current demographic composition.

This project suggests substantive implications for common human resource practices including:

- Referrals: Human Resources personnel should attend to the differences in the propensity of applicants from different ethnic backgrounds to activate social network ties and thus quality candidates will be overlooked when referrals are a core aspect of hiring. 

- Reviewing of resumes: Human Resources personnel should be wary of how applicants from different ethnic and class backgrounds list and describe personal hobbies on resumes. Ideally, they should not rely on personal hobbies to make hiring decisions because they are not correlated with performance and they are correlated with class and ethnic backgrounds. 

- Interaction styles in hiring interviews: Human Resources personnel should be made cognizant of the link between certain styles of interaction that are taught in elite educational backgrounds and perceptions of the "type" of person rewarded in elite occupations.

By highlighting subtle ways that the typical methods businesses use to select applicants disadvantage individuals from working class and non-White groups, we show how organizations are hindering their own efforts to diversify. This is particularly key in an era where AI and machine learning claim to promote non-biased, automated, hiring practices.

Modified by: Melissa Mazmanian
